subject: Science
note: Content vehicles for KS3 Science. Seeded from v4 teacher feedback (Osei). Covers Biology, Chemistry, and Physics investigations.

vehicles.name: Cell Structure and Microscopy
vehicles.description: Practical investigation using light microscopes to observe and compare plant and animal cells. Pupils prepare slides, draw scientific diagrams, and calculate magnification.
vehicles.recording_format: labelled scientific diagrams with magnification -> comparison table (plant vs animal cells) -> calculation of actual size
vehicles.safety_notes: Handle glass slides carefully. Iodine stains skin and clothing. Cheek cell collection requires hygiene protocol. Do not taste stains.
vehicles.expected_outcome: Pupils observe cell structures under the microscope, distinguish plant and animal cells, and calculate magnification. Plant cells have cell wall, chloroplasts, and permanent vacuole; animal cells do not.
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils prepare a microscope slide and focus the microscope correctly? Can they draw accurate labelled diagrams following scientific drawing conventions? Can they calculate magnification and actual size? Can they compare plant and animal cells?
success_criteria: Prepare a microscope slide and achieve focus at different magnifications
Draw labelled scientific diagrams following conventions
Calculate magnification using the formula: magnification = image size / actual size
Compare plant and animal cells, identifying key structural differences

vehicles.name: Acids, Alkalis and Neutralisation
vehicles.description: Practical investigation into pH, indicators, and neutralisation reactions. Pupils test household substances, use universal indicator, and carry out a neutralisation titration.
vehicles.variables_independent: type of substance tested / amount of alkali added
vehicles.recording_format: pH results table -> pH scale diagram -> neutralisation graph (pH vs volume of alkali added)
vehicles.safety_notes: Wear safety goggles and gloves. Use dilute acids and alkalis only. Wash splashes immediately. Know location of eyewash station.
vehicles.expected_outcome: Acids have pH below 7, alkalis above 7, neutral = 7. Neutralisation produces a salt and water. Universal indicator shows a colour spectrum across the pH scale.
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils use indicators to classify substances as acidic, alkaline, or neutral? Can they describe the pH scale? Can they explain neutralisation as a reaction between acid and alkali producing salt and water? Can they write a word equation?
success_criteria: Classify substances as acidic, alkaline, or neutral using indicators
Describe the pH scale from 0-14 with correct terminology
Explain neutralisation and write a word equation
Carry out a practical safely, recording results accurately

vehicles.name: Forces and Motion
vehicles.description: Investigation into speed, acceleration, and the effects of forces. Pupils calculate speed from distance-time data, investigate friction, and explore balanced/unbalanced forces.
vehicles.variables_independent: mass added to trolley / surface type
vehicles.variables_dependent: time to travel fixed distance / acceleration
vehicles.recording_format: distance-time data table -> speed calculation -> distance-time graph -> force diagram
vehicles.safety_notes: Ensure trolleys have end stops. Keep masses secure. Clear floor area.
vehicles.expected_outcome: Speed = distance / time. Unbalanced forces cause acceleration. Friction opposes motion. Gravity pulls objects towards Earth. Force diagrams show balanced and unbalanced forces.
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils calculate speed from distance-time data? Can they draw and interpret distance-time graphs? Can they draw force diagrams showing balanced and unbalanced forces? Can they explain the relationship between force, mass, and acceleration qualitatively?
success_criteria: Calculate speed using speed = distance / time
Draw and interpret distance-time graphs
Draw force diagrams for balanced and unbalanced situations
Explain how unbalanced forces cause changes in motion

vehicles.name: Photosynthesis Investigation
vehicles.description: Investigation into the factors affecting photosynthesis — light intensity and its effect on the rate of oxygen production in pondweed.
vehicles.variables_independent: distance of lamp from pondweed (light intensity)
vehicles.variables_dependent: number of oxygen bubbles per minute
vehicles.recording_format: results table (distance vs bubble count) -> graph of light intensity vs rate -> conclusion linking to photosynthesis equation
vehicles.safety_notes: Lamp gets hot — do not touch. Ensure water does not contact electrical equipment. Wash hands after handling pondweed.
vehicles.expected_outcome: As light intensity increases (lamp closer), rate of photosynthesis increases (more bubbles). At high light intensities, the rate levels off (limited by CO2 or temperature).
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils explain the word equation for photosynthesis? Can they design a fair test varying light intensity? Can they interpret their results in terms of rate of photosynthesis? Can they explain the concept of limiting factors?
success_criteria: State the word equation for photosynthesis
Design and carry out a fair test varying light intensity
Plot results on a graph and identify the pattern
Explain results using the concept of photosynthesis and limiting factors

vehicles.name: Particle Model and Changes of State
vehicles.description: Investigation into the particle model — observing and measuring changes of state, plotting heating/cooling curves, and explaining observations using particle theory.
vehicles.recording_format: temperature-time data table -> heating/cooling curve graph -> particle diagrams for each state
vehicles.safety_notes: Use water baths rather than direct heating where possible. Stearic acid is hot — use tongs. Wear safety goggles. Tie back hair near Bunsen burners.
vehicles.expected_outcome: Temperature stays constant during changes of state (melting, boiling). Particles in solids vibrate in fixed positions; in liquids they move freely; in gases they move rapidly in all directions. Energy is needed to change state.
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils draw particle diagrams for all three states? Can they interpret a heating/cooling curve and explain the flat sections? Can they explain changes of state in terms of energy and particle movement?
success_criteria: Draw accurate particle diagrams for solids, liquids, and gases
Plot and interpret a heating or cooling curve
Explain why temperature remains constant during changes of state
Use particle theory to explain properties of solids, liquids, and gases

vehicles.name: Ecosystem Relationships
vehicles.description: Fieldwork and research enquiry exploring food webs, interdependence, and the impact of environmental change on populations. Includes quadrat sampling.
vehicles.variables_independent: habitat location (e.g. sunny vs shaded area)
vehicles.recording_format: species tally table -> bar chart of distribution -> food web diagram -> impact analysis
vehicles.safety_notes: Outdoor fieldwork risk assessment required. Check for allergies. Wash hands after handling soil/organisms. Stay in designated areas.
vehicles.expected_outcome: Organisms in an ecosystem are interdependent. Food webs show complex feeding relationships. Environmental changes (e.g. removing a species, pollution) have knock-on effects through the ecosystem.
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils design a sampling strategy using quadrats? Can they construct and interpret food webs? Can they predict and explain the effects of environmental change on populations within an ecosystem?
success_criteria: Use quadrats to collect data on species distribution
Construct a food web from collected data
Explain the concept of interdependence with examples
Predict the effects of an environmental change on an ecosystem

vehicles.name: Energy Transfers and Resources
vehicles.description: Investigation into energy stores, transfers, and efficiency. Pupils investigate insulation, compare renewable and non-renewable energy resources, and calculate energy efficiency.
vehicles.variables_independent: insulation material (bubble wrap, foil, felt, newspaper, none)
vehicles.recording_format: temperature readings every 2 minutes -> cooling curve graph -> energy transfer diagram -> efficiency calculation
vehicles.safety_notes: Use warm water (not boiling) for pupil experiments. Teacher handles boiling water. Thermometers are fragile.
vehicles.expected_outcome: Energy is transferred from hot to cold objects. Better insulators reduce the rate of energy transfer. Energy cannot be created or destroyed. Efficiency = useful output / total input.
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils describe energy transfers using correct terminology (stores and pathways)? Can they calculate efficiency from given data? Can they evaluate the advantages and disadvantages of different energy resources?
success_criteria: Describe energy transfers using stores and pathways
Investigate insulation and present results graphically
Calculate energy efficiency from given data
Compare renewable and non-renewable energy resources

vehicles.name: Chemical Reactions: Metals and Acids
vehicles.description: Investigation into the reactions of metals with acids and water, establishing a reactivity series through practical observation and pattern identification.
vehicles.variables_independent: type of metal (magnesium, zinc, iron, copper)
vehicles.variables_dependent: vigour of reaction (observations: fizzing, temperature change, gas production)
variables_controlled: same volume and concentration of acid
vehicles.recording_format: observations table (metal, observations, temperature change) -> reactivity series ranking -> word equations
vehicles.safety_notes: Wear safety goggles and gloves. Magnesium reacts vigorously — use small pieces. Test for hydrogen with a lighted splint away from acid. Good ventilation required.
vehicles.expected_outcome: Metals react with acids to produce a salt and hydrogen. More reactive metals react more vigorously. The reactivity series ranks metals by their reactivity: Mg > Zn > Fe > Cu (copper does not react).
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils describe the pattern in metal reactivity from their observations? Can they write word equations for metal + acid reactions? Can they use the reactivity series to predict whether a displacement reaction will occur?
success_criteria: Describe observations when different metals react with acid
Rank metals in order of reactivity from practical evidence
Write word equations for metal + acid reactions
Predict displacement reactions using the reactivity series
